Cells divide uncontrollably forming tumours (1 mark)

1.6 Cell division, cell diversity and ce.question: Compare the roles of mitosis and meiosis in the life cycle of organisms. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Mitosis: growth, repair, asexual reproduction (1 mark)
Meiosis: production of gametes for sexual reproduction (1 mark)
Both ensure genetic continuity but meiosis introduces variation (1 mark)

1.6 Cell division, cell diversity and ce.question: Discuss the importance of stem cells in research. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Model systems to study development (1 mark)
Drug testing on differentiated cells (1 mark)
Study of genetic diseases (1 mark)
Understanding cell specialisation and differentiation (1 mark)

1.6 Cell division, cell diversity and ce.question: Explain how stem cells are used in the treatment of Type 1 diabetes. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Differentiate into insulin-producing beta cells (1 mark)
Transplanted into pancreas (1 mark)
Restore insulin secretion and blood glucose regulation (1 mark)

1.6 Cell division, cell diversity and ce.question: Describe how meiosis contributes to genetic variation in gametes. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Crossing over exchanges genetic material between homologous chromosomes (1 mark)
Independent assortment shuffles maternal/paternal chromosomes (1 mark)
Random segregation during anaphase I and II (1 mark)
Results in unique gametes (1 mark)

1.6 Cell division, cell diversity and ce.question: Evaluate the benefits and risks of using stem cells in regenerative medicine. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Benefits: replace damaged tissues, treat degenerative diseases, reduce transplant shortages (1 mark)
Potential to cure currently untreatable conditions (1 mark)
Risks: immune rejection, risk of tumours, ethical concerns (1 mark)
Embryonic stem cells raise moral issues (1 mark)
Adult stem cells less versatile (1 mark)
Induced pluripotent stem cells reduce ethical concerns but may have instability (1 mark)

1.6 Cell division, cell diversity and ce.question: Describe the sequence of events in the cell cycle and explain the significance of each stage. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: G1: cell growth, organelle replication (1 mark)
S: DNA replication (1 mark)
G2: preparation for mitosis (1 mark)
M phase: mitosis divides nucleus (1 mark)
Cytokinesis: cytoplasm division (1 mark)
Significance: ensures genetic continuity and cell viability (1 mark)

1.6 Cell division, cell diversity and ce.question: Discuss the adaptations of xylem, phloem, and guard cells in relation to their functions. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Xylem: lignified walls, hollow tubes → water transport/support (1 mark)
Phloem: sieve tubes with pores, companion cells → translocation of sugars (1 mark)
Guard cells: uneven thickening of walls, turgor changes → open/close stomata (1 mark)
All are specialised plant cells adapted for transport and regulation (1 mark)

1.6 Cell division, cell diversity and ce.question: Explain the role of meiosis in maintaining chromosome number across generations and promoting genetic diversity. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Reduces diploid to haploid to maintain stable chromosome number after fertilisation (1 mark)
Crossing over creates recombinant chromosomes (1 mark)
Independent assortment produces many combinations (1 mark)
Fertilisation further increases variation (1 mark)
Essential for evolution and adaptation (1 mark)
Maintains genetic stability within species (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Write the overall balanced equation for photosynthesis and name the energy source. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: 6CO2 + 6H2O → C6H12O6 + 6O2 (1 mark)
Light energy is the energy source and chlorophyll is required (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: State the specific site of the light-dependent reactions in a chloroplast. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Thylakoid membranes (grana) (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: State the site of the Calvin cycle in a chloroplast. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Stroma (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain the primary role of chlorophyll a in photosystems. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Acts at the reaction centre to donate excited electrons (1 mark)
Absorbs mainly red/blue light to initiate photochemistry (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Describe the relationship between absorption spectra and action spectra in photosynthesis. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Absorption spectrum shows wavelengths absorbed by pigments (1 mark)
Action spectrum shows photosynthetic rate vs wavelength (1 mark)
Peaks largely coincide because absorbed light drives photosynthesis (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Define photolysis of water. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Light-driven splitting of water into protons, electrons and oxygen (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Outline the main steps of non-cyclic photophosphorylation. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Light excites electrons in PSII (1 mark)
Electrons pass along an electron transport chain releasing energy (1 mark)
Energy pumps protons into thylakoid lumen creating a gradient (1 mark)
Photolysis of water replaces PSII electrons and releases O2 (1 mark)
Protons flow through ATP synthase to make ATP (chemiosmosis) (1 mark)
Electrons reach PSI, are re-excited and reduce NADP to NADPH (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Summarise cyclic photophosphorylation at PSI. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Light excites electrons in PSI which enter an electron transport chain (1 mark)
Energy from electron flow generates ATP via chemiosmosis (1 mark)
Electrons return to PSI; no NADPH or O2 is produced (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain chemiosmosis in the light-dependent reactions. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Electron transport drives proton pumping into the thylakoid lumen (1 mark)
Proton gradient produces a proton motive force across the membrane (1 mark)
Protons flow through ATP synthase, catalysing ATP formation (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Name the two immediate products of the light-dependent reactions that are used in the Calvin cycle. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: ATP (1 mark)
Reduced NADP (NADPH) (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: State the roles of ATP and NADPH in the Calvin cycle. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: ATP provides energy/phosphorylation for reduction reactions (1 mark)
NADPH provides reducing power (hydrogen/electrons) (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Outline the stages of the Calvin cycle from CO2 fixation to RuBP regeneration. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: CO2 combines with RuBP catalysed by RuBisCO (1 mark)
Unstable 6-carbon intermediate forms two GP molecules (1 mark)
GP is reduced to TP using NADPH (1 mark)
ATP provides energy/phosphate for the reduction step (1 mark)
Some TP leaves the cycle to form sugars (1 mark)
Most TP is used (with ATP) to regenerate RuBP (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain the function of the enzyme RuBisCO. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Catalyses the fixation of CO2 to RuBP (carboxylation) (1 mark)
Initiates the Calvin cycle by forming GP (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Describe two possible fates of triose phosphate (TP). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Used to synthesise hexose sugars/starch/cellulose (1 mark)
Recycled to regenerate RuBP (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: How many turns of the Calvin cycle are required to produce one molecule of glucose and why? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Six turns are required (1 mark)
Because 6 CO2 are needed to provide the carbon for one C6 sugar (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Define a limiting factor in photosynthesis. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A factor that, when in short supply, restricts the rate of photosynthesis (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain how low temperature limits the rate of photosynthesis. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Enzyme activity in the Calvin cycle decreases (1 mark)
Reduced kinetic energy lowers collision frequency (1 mark)
Slower GP → TP conversion and RuBP regeneration (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Describe the effect of increasing light intensity on photosynthetic rate when CO2 and temperature are non-limiting. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Rate increases as more ATP and NADPH are generated (1 mark)
Eventually plateaus when another factor becomes limiting (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain how low carbon dioxide concentration affects Calvin cycle intermediates. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Less CO2 fixation reduces GP formation (1 mark)
RuBP accumulates due to reduced carboxylation (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Describe an investigation to measure the effect of light intensity on photosynthesis using an aquatic plant. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Use Elodea/Cabomba and count oxygen bubbles or measure O2 with a sensor (1 mark)
Vary distance/light intensity with a lamp and light meter (1 mark)
Control temperature and CO2 (e.g., sodium hydrogencarbonate) (1 mark)
Repeat and calculate mean rates at each intensity (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Write the formula used to calculate Rf values in pigment chromatography. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Rf = distance moved by pigment ÷ distance moved by solvent front (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain why different photosynthetic pigments separate during chromatography. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Pigments differ in solubility in the solvent (1 mark)
Pigments differ in affinity to the stationary phase (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain why the action spectrum does not match exactly the absorption spectrum of chlorophyll alone. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Accessory pigments absorb additional wavelengths (1 mark)
Energy is funnelled to reaction centres via antenna complexes (1 mark)
Whole-leaf processes and internal CO2 availability influence overall rate (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Describe three chloroplast adaptations that maximise photosynthetic efficiency. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Extensive thylakoid membranes increase surface area for light reactions (1 mark)
Stroma contains enzymes and is close to thylakoids for rapid transfer (1 mark)
Own DNA/ribosomes enable rapid synthesis of key proteins (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: State the role of accessory pigments within a photosystem. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Broaden the range of wavelengths absorbed (1 mark)
Transfer excitation energy to chlorophyll a at the reaction centre (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Why is green light least effective at driving photosynthesis in most plants? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Green light is mostly reflected/transmitted, not absorbed (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Define photorespiration and state its effect on photosynthetic efficiency. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: RuBisCO uses O2 instead of CO2 (oxygenation of RuBP) (1 mark)
Produces phosphoglycolate that must be recycled (1 mark)
Wastes energy and reduces net carbon fixation (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain one advantage of the C4 pathway in hot, bright conditions. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: CO2 is concentrated around RuBisCO in bundle sheath cells (1 mark)
Reduces photorespiration at high temperatures (1 mark)
Maintains higher photosynthetic rates under intense light (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Describe how stomatal regulation presents a trade-off for photosynthesis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Opening stomata increases CO2 uptake (1 mark)
But increases water loss by transpiration (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain how water stress can indirectly reduce photosynthetic rate. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Water stress causes stomata to close (1 mark)
Lower CO2 entry reduces Calvin cycle activity (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Interpret a graph where photosynthetic rate increases with light then plateaus despite further light increase. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Initial rise shows light is limiting (1 mark)
Plateau indicates another factor (CO2 or temperature) is limiting (1 mark)
Further light cannot increase rate without removing the new limitation (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain why ATP synthase is embedded in the thylakoid membrane. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: It uses the trans-thylakoid proton gradient (1 mark)
Provides a channel and catalytic site for ATP formation (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: During illumination, why does the pH of the stroma rise while the thylakoid lumen becomes acidic? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Protons are pumped into the thylakoid lumen and produced by photolysis (1 mark)
Proton removal from stroma increases stromal pH (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain why the Calvin cycle is termed light-independent yet its rate depends on light. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Reactions do not require light directly (1 mark)
But depend on ATP and NADPH generated by the light-dependent reactions (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Why does temperature usually affect the light-independent reactions more than the light-dependent reactions? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Calvin cycle steps are enzyme-catalysed (temperature sensitive) (1 mark)
Light reactions are driven primarily by photon energy and membranes (less temperature sensitive) (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Write a balanced equation for the photolysis of one water molecule. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: H2O → 2H+ + 2e− + ½O2 (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Name two biosynthetic uses of triose phosphate (TP) other than glucose. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Synthesis of glycerol/fatty acids → lipids (1 mark)
Synthesis of amino acids/proteins (using nitrogen) (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Name the coenzyme that is reduced in the light-dependent reactions. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: NADP (reduced to NADPH) (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: State the role of the thylakoid electron transport chain. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Transfers electrons between carriers at decreasing energy levels (1 mark)
Releases energy to pump protons for ATP synthesis (1 mark)

2.1 Photosynthesis.question: Explain how glycerate-3-phosphate (GP) is converted to triose phosphate (TP). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: GP is reduced using NADPH as a reducing agent (1 mark)
ATP provides energy/phosphorylation for the reduction (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Define cellular respiration. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The controlled release of energy from organic molecules to produce ATP (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: State the immediate energy currency of the cell. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: ATP (adenosine triphosphate) (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Where in the cell does glycolysis occur? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Cytosol/cytoplasm (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Name the two coenzymes commonly reduced during respiration. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: NAD (reduced to NADH) (1 mark)
FAD (reduced to FADH2) (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Outline the net ATP yield from glycolysis per glucose molecule. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Net gain of 2 ATP (4 made, 2 used) (1 mark)
2 NADH produced (potential for further ATP via oxidative phosphorylation) (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain what is meant by substrate-level phosphorylation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: ATP formation by direct transfer of a phosphate group from a phosphorylated intermediate to ADP (1 mark)
Occurs in glycolysis and Krebs cycle (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Describe the fate of pyruvate in aerobic conditions in eukaryotes. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Transported into the mitochondrial matrix (1 mark)
Decarboxylated and dehydrogenated to form acetyl group (1 mark)
Acetyl group combines with CoA to form acetyl-CoA (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: State the products of the link reaction per pyruvate. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: 1 NADH (1 mark)
1 CO2 (1 mark)
1 acetyl-CoA (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: List three features of mitochondria that aid aerobic respiration. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Highly folded inner membrane (cristae) increases surface area for ETC and ATP synthase (1 mark)
Matrix contains enzymes for link reaction and Krebs cycle (1 mark)
Intermembrane space allows proton accumulation for chemiosmosis (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Outline the first two steps when acetyl-CoA enters the Krebs cycle. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Acetyl (2C) combines with oxaloacetate (4C) to form citrate (6C) (1 mark)
Citrate is isomerised to isocitrate (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: State, per turn of the Krebs cycle (per acetyl-CoA), the number of CO2, NADH, FADH2 and ATP (or GTP) produced. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: 2 CO2 (1 mark)
3 NADH (1 mark)
1 FADH2 (1 mark)
1 ATP (or GTP) by substrate-level phosphorylation (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain the role of oxygen in oxidative phosphorylation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Final electron acceptor at the end of the electron transport chain (1 mark)
Combines with electrons and protons to form water (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Describe chemiosmosis in mitochondria. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Electron transport releases energy used to pump protons into the intermembrane space (1 mark)
Proton gradient creates a proton motive force across the inner membrane (1 mark)
Protons flow through ATP synthase driving ATP synthesis from ADP and Pi (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Compare the ATP yield from NADH and FADH2 via the electron transport chain. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: NADH donates electrons to Complex I, generally producing more ATP (1 mark)
FADH2 donates to Complex II (skips Complex I), producing slightly less ATP (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Define respiratory quotient (RQ) and give its formula. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: RQ is the ratio of CO2 produced to O2 consumed during respiration (1 mark)
RQ = CO2 produced / O2 consumed (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: State typical RQ values for carbohydrates, lipids and proteins. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Carbohydrates ≈ 1.0 (1 mark)
Lipids ≈ 0.7 (1 mark)
Proteins ≈ 0.8–0.9 (accept 0.8) (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain why the theoretical maximum ATP yield per glucose is rarely achieved in cells. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Proton leak across the inner mitochondrial membrane (1 mark)
ATP used to transport ADP, Pi and pyruvate (1 mark)
Shuttle systems for cytosolic NADH may yield fewer ATP (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Describe lactate fermentation in mammals. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Occurs in cytosol under anaerobic conditions (1 mark)
Pyruvate is reduced to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (1 mark)
NADH is oxidised to NAD+ allowing glycolysis to continue (1 mark)
Lactate can be transported to liver for conversion back to pyruvate/glucose (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Describe alcoholic fermentation in yeast. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Pyruvate is decarboxylated to ethanal (1 mark)
Ethanol is formed by reduction of ethanal using NADH (1 mark)
NADH is oxidised to regenerate NAD+ (1 mark)
Occurs in cytosol under anaerobic conditions (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain why glycolysis can continue during anaerobic respiration. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Fermentation pathways regenerate NAD+ from NADH (1 mark)
NAD+ is required for glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase in glycolysis (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: State two reasons why aerobic respiration yields more ATP than anaerobic pathways. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Oxidative phosphorylation generates large amounts of ATP using oxygen (1 mark)
Complete oxidation of glucose to CO2 extracts more energy than partial oxidation to lactate/ethanol (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Define oxygen debt. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The extra oxygen required after exercise to oxidise accumulated lactate and restore ATP/creatine phosphate (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Name the four main stages of aerobic respiration in correct order. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Glycolysis, link reaction, Krebs cycle, oxidative phosphorylation (1 mark each up to two)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain the role of dehydrogenation and decarboxylation in the Krebs cycle. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Dehydrogenation transfers hydrogen/electrons to NAD/FAD forming reduced coenzymes (1 mark)
Decarboxylation releases CO2, shortening carbon chains (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Calculate the net ATP directly produced by substrate-level phosphorylation per glucose across glycolysis and Krebs (include both turns). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Glycolysis: 2 ATP net (1 mark)
Krebs: 2 ATP total (1 per turn) so 4 ATP in total by substrate-level phosphorylation (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: State one way lipids can be used as respiratory substrates. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Fatty acids are broken to acetyl-CoA via beta-oxidation (1 mark)
Acetyl-CoA enters the Krebs cycle for further oxidation (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain how amino acids can feed into respiration. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Amino acids are deaminated to remove the amino group (1 mark)
Carbon skeletons are converted to pyruvate, acetyl-CoA or Krebs intermediates (1 mark)
These enter respiration to be oxidised for ATP production (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Describe how a simple respirometer can measure the rate of respiration in seeds. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Germinating seeds in a sealed apparatus with soda lime/potassium hydroxide to absorb CO2 (1 mark)
O2 consumption reduces gas volume/pressure (1 mark)
Coloured fluid in capillary moves toward the seeds (1 mark)
Measure distance moved per unit time and convert to O2 uptake rate (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Define Q10 and explain how it relates to respiration rate. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Q10 is the factor by which a rate changes for a 10°C temperature increase (1 mark)
Respiration rate typically roughly doubles with a 10°C rise up to an optimum (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain why cyanide is a metabolic poison affecting respiration. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Inhibits cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) in the ETC (1 mark)
Prevents electron transfer to oxygen, halting oxidative phosphorylation (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Describe the structural relationship between ATP synthase and the proton gradient. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: ATP synthase spans the inner mitochondrial membrane (1 mark)
Proton flow through the F0 channel drives rotation of the complex (1 mark)
Mechanical rotation promotes ATP formation in the F1 catalytic head (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: A yeast culture produces more ethanol at higher glucose concentrations but total ATP per glucose falls. Explain. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: High glucose and limited oxygen push metabolism toward fermentation (1 mark)
Fermentation yields only 2 ATP per glucose vs aerobic yield (1 mark)
Rate increases but efficiency (ATP per glucose) decreases (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain why brown adipose tissue generates heat rather than ATP efficiently. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Contains uncoupling protein (UCP1) in inner mitochondrial membrane (1 mark)
Protons leak back without passing through ATP synthase (1 mark)
Energy of gradient is released as heat (non-shivering thermogenesis) (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Outline the investment and payoff phases of glycolysis. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Investment: ATP used to phosphorylate glucose to hexose bisphosphate (2 ATP used) (1 mark)
Cleavage: hexose bisphosphate split to two triose phosphates (1 mark)
Payoff: triose phosphates oxidised to pyruvate, generating NADH (1 mark)
Net 2 ATP produced by substrate-level phosphorylation (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: State two differences between mitochondrial and chloroplast chemiosmosis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Mitochondria use electrons from NADH/FADH2; chloroplasts use light-excited electrons (1 mark)
Protons pumped to intermembrane space vs thylakoid lumen respectively (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Predict and explain the effect of an inner mitochondrial membrane uncoupler on oxygen consumption and ATP yield. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Oxygen consumption increases as ETC runs faster to maintain gradient (1 mark)
ATP yield decreases because proton gradient is dissipated without ATP synthesis (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain why the presence of oxygen allows more complete oxidation of NADH. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Oxygen accepts electrons at the end of the ETC (1 mark)
This regenerates NAD+ continuously, allowing dehydrogenase reactions to proceed (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Calculate total reduced coenzymes produced from one glucose by link reaction and Krebs cycle combined (not including glycolysis). [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Per glucose there are 2 pyruvate, so link reaction occurs twice (1 mark)
Link: 2 NADH total (1 per pyruvate) (1 mark)
Krebs (2 turns): 6 NADH and 2 FADH2 (1 mark)

2.2 Respiration.question: Explain why prolonged anaerobic respiration in muscle is unsustainable. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lactate accumulation lowers pH inhibiting enzymes (1 mark)
Low ATP yield cannot meet high energy demand (1 mark)
Glycogen stores become depleted (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Define a tropism. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A directional growth response of a plant to a stimulus (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Name two plant hormones involved in growth regulation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Auxin (IAA) (1 mark)
Gibberellin (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Explain how auxin (IAA) brings about positive phototropism in shoots. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Light causes uneven auxin distribution, higher on the shaded side (1 mark)
Auxin stimulates cell elongation in shoot cells (1 mark)
Greater elongation on shaded side bends shoot towards light (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Describe the role of gibberellins in seed germination. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Embryo releases gibberellins upon imbibition (1 mark)
Stimulates aleurone layer to produce hydrolytic enzymes (e.g. amylase) (1 mark)
Enzymes mobilise starch to sugars for embryo growth (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Explain apical dominance and evidence from decapitation experiments. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Apical bud inhibits lateral bud growth via auxin (1 mark)
Removing the apex relieves inhibition; lateral buds grow (1 mark)
Applying auxin paste to cut stump restores inhibition (1 mark)
Shows auxin produced at apex controls lateral growth (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Outline how abscisic acid (ABA) brings about stomatal closure during drought. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: ABA binds guard cell receptors (1 mark)
Causes ion efflux (e.g. K+) from guard cells (1 mark)
Water leaves by osmosis, turgor falls (1 mark)
Guard cells become flaccid and stomata close (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Give two commercial uses of plant hormones. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Auxin as rooting powder to stimulate cuttings (1 mark)
Ethene for fruit ripening (or gibberellins for seedless fruit) (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Distinguish between taxis and kinesis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Taxis: directional movement towards/away from a stimulus (1 mark)
Kinesis: non-directional change in activity rate in response to stimulus intensity (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Define innate and learned behaviour, with one example each. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Innate: genetically programmed (e.g. withdrawal reflex) (1 mark)
Learned: modified by experience (e.g. habituation to repeated stimuli) (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Outline habituation and its adaptive advantage. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Decreased response to repeated, harmless stimuli (1 mark)
Results from synaptic changes reducing transmitter release/response (1 mark)
Saves energy and attention for important stimuli (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Compare classical and operant conditioning. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Classical: association between neutral and unconditioned stimulus (1 mark)
Operant: behaviour shaped by reinforcement/punishment (1 mark)
Operant depends on consequences; classical on stimulus pairing (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Name four major brain regions and one function of each. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Cerebrum: higher thought/voluntary actions (1 mark)
Cerebellum: coordination/balance (1 mark)
Medulla oblongata: autonomic control (heart/ventilation) (1 mark)
Hypothalamus/pituitary: homeostasis/endocrine control (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Describe the knee-jerk reflex arc. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Stretch receptor in quadriceps detects tendon tap (1 mark)
Sensory neuron to spinal cord (1 mark)
Direct synapse to motor neuron (monosynaptic) (1 mark)
Motor neuron triggers quadriceps contraction/leg extension (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: State two benefits of reflex actions. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Rapid response protects from harm (1 mark)
Automatic; does not require conscious processing (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Differentiate somatic and autonomic nervous systems. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Somatic: voluntary control of skeletal muscle (1 mark)
Autonomic: involuntary control of smooth/cardiac muscle and glands (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Contrast sympathetic and parasympathetic effects on heart and bronchi. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Sympathetic increases heart rate and dilates bronchi (1 mark)
Parasympathetic decreases heart rate and constricts bronchi (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Describe transmission at a cholinergic synapse. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: AP arrives; Ca2+ channels open; Ca2+ enters presynaptic terminal (1 mark)
Vesicles fuse with membrane; ACh released into cleft (1 mark)
ACh diffuses and binds postsynaptic receptors (1 mark)
Na+ channels open; EPSP generated (1 mark)
ACh is broken down by acetylcholinesterase to acetate + choline (1 mark)
Choline reuptake; vesicles refilled with ACh (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Give two reasons synaptic transmission is unidirectional. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Neurotransmitter vesicles only in presynaptic terminal (1 mark)
Receptors only on postsynaptic membrane (1 mark)

1.5 Plant and animal responses.question: Describe the neuromuscular junction and one difference from a neurone–neurone synapse. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Motor neuron terminal releases ACh onto muscle end-plate (1 mark)
ACh binds nicotinic receptors causing end-plate potential (1 mark)
Leads to muscle AP via T-tubules and contraction (1 mark)
Always excitatory; synapse uses AChE in basal lamina (1 mark)

Site of hormonal influence (aldosterone) on Na+ reabsorption (1 mark)

Malnutrition/immunosuppression (e.g., HIV) (1 mark)
Poor sanitation/hygiene or climate favouring pathogens (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Give three factors that increase transmission of disease in crops. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: High planting density/monocultures (1 mark)
Warm, moist conditions/high humidity (1 mark)
Contaminated tools/propagules and movement of stock (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Name three non-specific primary defences of the human body. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Skin and keratinised barrier (1 mark)
Mucus + ciliated epithelium in airways (1 mark)
Stomach acid/lysozyme in secretions (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Describe the main stages of blood clotting at a wound. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Platelets/tissue damage release thromboplastin (clotting factors) (1 mark)
Prothrombin → thrombin (Ca²⁺ and vitamin K dependent) (1 mark)
Thrombin converts fibrinogen → fibrin (insoluble fibres) (1 mark)
Fibrin mesh traps cells forming a clot then scab (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Explain how inflammation helps prevent infection. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Mast cells release histamine (1 mark)
Vasodilation and increased capillary permeability cause oedema (1 mark)
Phagocytes migrate to site (chemotaxis) (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Outline four key steps of phagocytosis. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Chemotaxis and recognition (often via opsonins) (1 mark)
Engulfment → phagosome formation (1 mark)
Phagosome fuses with lysosome; enzymes digest pathogen (1 mark)
Antigen presentation on MHC (macrophages as APCs) (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Give two differences between neutrophils and macrophages. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Neutrophils: short-lived, multi-lobed nuclei; rapid responders (1 mark)
Macrophages: longer-lived, act as antigen-presenting cells (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: What is an opsonin and what is its role? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: A molecule (e.g., antibody/complement) that binds to pathogens (1 mark)
Enhances phagocyte attachment via specific receptors (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Define an antigen-presenting cell (APC). [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A cell displaying processed antigen on MHC to activate lymphocytes (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Outline the cell-mediated (T cell) immune response. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: APCs present antigen to T helper cells (CD4) (1 mark)
Clonal selection of specific T cells (1 mark)
Clonal expansion to T helper, T killer (cytotoxic), T memory, Treg (1 mark)
T killer destroy infected cells; T helper release cytokines (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Outline the humoral (B cell) immune response. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: T helper cells activate selected B cells (1 mark)
B cells undergo clonal expansion (mitosis) (1 mark)
Plasma cells secrete specific antibodies (1 mark)
B memory cells formed for secondary response (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: State the roles of T helper, T killer and T regulatory cells. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: T helper: secrete interleukins to activate B/T cells (1 mark)
T killer: perforin/granzyme-mediated lysis of infected cells (1 mark)
T regulatory: suppress immune response, prevent autoimmunity (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Distinguish plasma B cells and B memory cells. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Plasma cells: short-lived, secrete large amounts of antibody (1 mark)
B memory cells: long-lived, enable rapid secondary response (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Compare the primary and secondary immune responses. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Primary: longer latent period, lower antibody titre (1 mark)
Secondary: faster, higher titre due to memory cells (1 mark)
Secondary antibodies persist longer/greater affinity (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Describe the structure of an antibody. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Two heavy and two light polypeptide chains (1 mark)
Variable regions form specific antigen-binding sites (1 mark)
Constant region and hinge region for flexibility (1 mark)
Disulfide bonds stabilize the quaternary structure (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: State three ways antibodies aid in pathogen removal. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Neutralisation of toxins/virus binding sites (1 mark)
Agglutination to enhance phagocytosis (1 mark)
Opsonisation/complement activation (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Give three applications of monoclonal antibodies. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Diagnostic tests (e.g., pregnancy tests/ELISA) (1 mark)
Targeted cancer therapy/drug delivery (1 mark)
Measuring hormone/pathogen levels in assays (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Define vaccination and how it confers protection. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Deliberate exposure to antigenic material (safe form) (1 mark)
Stimulates immune response producing memory cells (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Explain herd immunity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: High proportion of population immunised reduces transmission (1 mark)
Indirectly protects non-immune/vulnerable individuals (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: What is ring vaccination and when is it used? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Vaccinating all people/animals in surrounding area/contacts of a case (1 mark)
Deployed to contain outbreaks by breaking transmission chains (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Name three types of vaccine exemplars. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Live attenuated pathogen (1 mark)
Inactivated/killed pathogen (1 mark)
Subunit/toxoid/recombinant antigen vaccine (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: What is an autoimmune disease? Give one example and a treatment approach. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Immune system attacks self-antigens (1 mark)
Example: type 1 diabetes/rheumatoid arthritis/SLE (1 mark)
Managed with immunosuppressants/steroids/monoclonal antibodies (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Differentiate bactericidal and bacteriostatic antibiotics. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Bactericidal: kill bacteria (1 mark)
Bacteriostatic: inhibit growth/reproduction (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Explain MRSA and Clostridioides difficile as healthcare-associated infections and one control measure for each. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: MRSA: Staphylococcus aureus resistant to methicillin/β-lactams (1 mark)
Control: strict hand hygiene/isolation/screening (1 mark)
C. difficile: overgrows after antibiotics disrupt gut flora (1 mark)
Control: prudent antibiotic use/environmental decontamination (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Give four drivers/solutions regarding antibiotic resistance. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Overuse/misuse of antibiotics selects resistance (1 mark)
Incomplete courses leave survivors (1 mark)
Horizontal gene transfer spreads resistance genes (1 mark)
Stewardship, surveillance, narrow-spectrum use/new drug development (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: State four sources/approaches for discovering new medicines. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Natural products from plants/microbes (1 mark)
Bioprospecting informed by traditional medicine (1 mark)
Pharmacogenomics/personalised medicine (1 mark)
Synthetic biology/rational drug design/phage therapy (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: List three physical (structural) defences of plants against pathogens. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Cellulose cell walls and lignification (1 mark)
Waxy cuticle/bark (1 mark)
Stomatal closure/tylose formation (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: List three chemical defences of plants. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Phenols/tannins inhibiting pathogens/herbivores (1 mark)
Alkaloids/terpenoids with antimicrobial activity (1 mark)
Hydrolytic enzymes (chitinases/glucanases/lysozymes) (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Describe three active plant defences after pathogen recognition. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Callose deposition at plasmodesmata/sieve plates (1 mark)
Oxidative burst and pathogenesis-related proteins (1 mark)
Localised necrosis/hypersensitive response (1 mark)

1.1 Communicable diseases, disease preve.question: Give four key steps of aseptic technique when culturing microorganisms. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Disinfect work area/wash hands; flame sterilise tools (1 mark)
Work near a flame/sterile field; minimise exposure time (1 mark)
Flame bottle necks; lift lids minimally and at an angle (1 mark)
Label/seal plates; incubate inverted at safe temperatures (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Define biodiversity. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The variety of life in an area, considering diversity within and between species and of ecosystems (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Name the three levels at which biodiversity is usually described. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Habitat (ecosystem) diversity (1 mark)
Species diversity (richness and evenness) (1 mark)
Genetic diversity within species (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Define species richness. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The number of different species present in a habitat (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Define species evenness. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: How similar the abundances of different species are in a community (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Explain why both species richness and evenness are needed to compare biodiversity between sites. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Richness alone ignores how individuals are distributed among species (1 mark)
Evenness shows whether communities are dominated or balanced, refining comparisons (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Write the Simpson’s Index of Diversity formula and state what a higher value indicates. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: D = 1 − Σ(n/N)² where n = number of individuals of each species; N = total individuals (1 mark)
Higher D indicates greater biodiversity and stability (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: List two reasons why Simpson’s Index is preferred over species richness alone. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: It incorporates species evenness via relative abundances (1 mark)
It is less sensitive to sampling extra rare species only (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Outline the steps for random sampling of plants with quadrats to reduce bias. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lay out axes and use random coordinates to position quadrats (1 mark)
Use consistent quadrat size and recording method (e.g., % cover) (1 mark)
Ensure sufficient number of replicates for reliability (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Distinguish systematic from stratified sampling and give one use for each. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Systematic: samples at regular intervals (e.g., along a transect) (1 mark)
Use: studying zonation along an environmental gradient (1 mark)
Stratified: sampling proportional to known groups/strata (1 mark)
Use: habitats with distinct sub-areas of different sizes (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Give two ways to improve reliability when estimating % cover with a point quadrat. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Increase number of points/replicate quadrats (1 mark)
Standardise placement and observer training to reduce subjectivity (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Name three animal sampling techniques and a typical target group for each. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Pitfall traps—ground-dwelling invertebrates (1 mark)
Sweep netting—flying/vegetation-dwelling insects (1 mark)
Kick-sampling—freshwater invertebrates (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Explain the Lincoln Index (capture–mark–recapture) assumption that can be violated and its consequence. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Assumes marked and unmarked individuals mix randomly and marking does not affect survival (1 mark)
Violation biases population estimates high or low (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: State two ethical considerations when conducting field sampling. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Minimise harm/stress and release animals promptly (1 mark)
Avoid habitat damage and obtain permissions (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Define genetic diversity and give one way it can be measured. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Variation of alleles/genes within a population (1 mark)
Measured by heterozygosity or number of polymorphic loci (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Describe two ways agriculture can reduce biodiversity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Monocultures and removal of hedgerows reduce habitat complexity (1 mark)
Use of pesticides/herbicides reduces non-target species (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Explain how deforestation can lead to loss of biodiversity at the genetic, species and habitat levels. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Habitat loss fragments populations (1 mark)
Smaller, isolated populations lose genetic diversity via drift (1 mark)
Local extinctions reduce species diversity (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Give two ecological reasons for maintaining biodiversity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Keystone species maintain community structure (1 mark)
High diversity increases ecosystem resilience/stability (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Give two economic reasons for conserving biodiversity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Ecosystem services (pollination, water purification, soil fertility) (1 mark)
Sources of medicines/materials and ecotourism (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Explain the role of keystone species with a named example. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: A species with disproportionate effect on community structure (1 mark)
Removal causes trophic cascades or major change (1 mark)
Example such as sea otters controlling urchins in kelp forests (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Define in situ conservation and give two examples. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Protecting species in their natural habitat (1 mark)
Wildlife reserves/national parks (1 mark)
Marine conservation zones or legal protection of habitats (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Define ex situ conservation and give two examples. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Conserving species outside their natural habitats (1 mark)
Captive breeding and reintroduction programmes (1 mark)
Seed banks/botanic gardens or cryopreservation (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: State two advantages of in situ over ex situ conservation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Maintains species within functioning ecosystems and natural behaviours (1 mark)
Conserves more species/habitat processes simultaneously (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: State two advantages of ex situ conservation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Protects individuals when in situ threats are extreme (1 mark)
Controlled breeding/genetic management is possible (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: List two potential problems with captive breeding and reintroduction. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Loss of genetic diversity/inbreeding (1 mark)
Behavioural changes or low survival post-release (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Describe two roles of seed banks in biodiversity conservation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Long-term storage of genetic diversity for future restoration/breeding (1 mark)
Insurance against extinction and crop wild relative preservation (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: State two storage conditions used by seed banks to prolong viability. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Dry seeds at low moisture content (1 mark)
Low temperatures (e.g., −20 °C) with periodic viability testing (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Name two international agreements relevant to biodiversity conservation and state a key aim of each. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: CITES—controls trade in endangered species/products (1 mark)
Aims to prevent over-exploitation via permits/lists (1 mark)
Convention on Biological Diversity—promotes conservation and sustainable use (1 mark)
Aims for fair sharing of genetic resource benefits (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Give two features of effective reserve design to maximise biodiversity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Sufficiently large with habitat connectivity/corridors (1 mark)
Minimised edge effects and representative habitat variety (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Explain species–area relationships in the context of reserve size. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Larger areas tend to support more species (S ∝ A^z) (1 mark)
Because larger habitats contain more niches and lower extinction risk (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Describe how succession can be managed to maintain biodiversity in a grassland reserve. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Grazing/mowing to prevent scrub encroachment (1 mark)
Rotational cutting to create mosaics of sward ages (1 mark)
Scrub removal or controlled burning where appropriate (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: List three indicators that can be monitored to assess biodiversity trends over time. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Species richness/evenness or Simpson’s Index (1 mark)
Population trends of indicator/keystone species (1 mark)
Habitat extent/quality metrics (e.g., canopy cover, deadwood) (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Explain how climate change can alter biodiversity via range shifts and phenology. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Species shift distributions poleward/upslope (1 mark)
Timing of life-cycle events (flowering/migration) changes (1 mark)
Mismatches in interactions (e.g., pollinators–plants) can reduce fitness (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Give two legal or policy tools used nationally to protect biodiversity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Protected site designations/licensing for protected species (1 mark)
Agri-environment schemes encouraging habitat-friendly farming (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Explain what a biodiversity action plan (BAP) or management plan should include. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Clear conservation targets and priority species/habitats (1 mark)
Evidence-based actions with timelines and responsibilities (1 mark)
Monitoring and adaptive management framework (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: A meadow shows high richness but low evenness dominated by two grasses. Predict how Simpson’s Index compares to a balanced meadow with fewer species. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Dominance lowers Simpson’s Index despite high richness (1 mark)
Balanced meadow may have higher D due to greater evenness (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Design a transect-based study to compare plant biodiversity from woodland edge to interior. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Lay belt or line transect perpendicular to edge (1 mark)
Place quadrats at fixed intervals (systematic sampling) (1 mark)
Record % cover/abundance for all species (1 mark)
Calculate richness/evenness and Simpson’s Index per point (1 mark)
Control time/season and observer consistency (1 mark)
Analyse trends with distance; replicate transects for reliability (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Explain how invasive non-native species threaten biodiversity. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Outcompete native species for resources (1 mark)
Alter habitats/food webs or introduce diseases (1 mark)
Reduce genetic diversity via hybridisation in some cases (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Give two reasons why genetic diversity is vital for long-term species survival. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Provides raw material for adaptation to environmental change (1 mark)
Reduces inbreeding depression and associated fitness costs (1 mark)

2.1 Biodiversity.question: Suggest two management actions to increase farmland biodiversity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Create/maintain hedgerows, field margins and flower strips (1 mark)
Reduce pesticide use and adopt mixed cropping/rotations (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Define taxonomy and state its main purpose. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Taxonomy is the science of naming and classifying organisms to reflect relationships and allow universal communication (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Write the correct hierarchical order of taxonomic ranks from domain to species. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Domain, Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus, Species (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: State the rules for writing a binomial name using the example of human beings. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Genus with capital letter, species lower case (Homo sapiens) (1 mark)
Written in italics or underlined when handwritten (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Distinguish between classification and phylogeny. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Classification groups organisms into taxa based on shared characteristics (1 mark)
Phylogeny shows evolutionary relationships/history among organisms (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain two lines of evidence used to infer phylogenetic relationships. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Comparative molecular data (DNA/rRNA/protein sequences) (1 mark)
Comparative anatomy/fossil record/morphology (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Outline three differences between the five-kingdom model and the three-domain system. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Three domains: Bacteria, Archaea, Eukarya; reflect molecular differences (1 mark)
Archaea separated from bacteria based on rRNA and membrane/lipid genes (1 mark)
Domains sit above kingdoms; classification emphasises evolutionary ancestry (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Define a species according to the biological species concept. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspring and are reproductively isolated from other groups (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Give two limitations of the biological species concept. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Cannot be applied to asexual or extinct (fossil) organisms (1 mark)
Hybridisation and ring species blur reproductive boundaries (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain what a clade is and what a node represents on a phylogenetic tree. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Clade: a monophyletic group including an ancestor and all its descendants (1 mark)
Node: a common ancestor where lineages diverge (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Describe two features of cladistics. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Uses shared derived characters (synapomorphies) to build trees (1 mark)
Applies parsimony—prefers the simplest tree with fewest changes (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: List three types of reproductive isolation that can lead to speciation. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Prezygotic: temporal/behavioural/ecological isolation (1 mark)
Prezygotic: mechanical/gametic isolation (1 mark)
Postzygotic: hybrid inviability/sterility (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Differentiate allopatric and sympatric speciation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Allopatric: speciation after geographical isolation (1 mark)
Sympatric: speciation without physical separation (e.g., polyploidy/ecological niches) (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain convergent evolution and give one example. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Unrelated lineages evolve similar adaptations due to similar selection pressures (1 mark)
Example: streamlined bodies in dolphins (mammals) and sharks (fish) (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Distinguish homologous from analogous structures with an example of each. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Homologous: same ancestral origin, different functions (e.g., vertebrate forelimbs) (1 mark)
Analogous: different origin, similar function (e.g., insect wing vs bird wing) (1 mark)
Homology evidences divergent evolution; analogy evidences convergence (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Outline natural selection as a mechanism of evolution. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Variation exists within populations due to mutations and meiosis (1 mark)
Selection pressures mean some variants have higher fitness (1 mark)
Better adapted individuals survive and reproduce more (1 mark)
Beneficial alleles increase in frequency over generations (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain adaptive radiation with a named example. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Rapid diversification from a common ancestor into multiple niches (1 mark)
Driven by different selection pressures in new environments (1 mark)
Example: Darwin’s finches evolving different beak forms (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Compare stabilising and directional selection, each with an example. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Stabilising: selects against extremes, maintains mean (e.g., human birth mass) (1 mark)
Directional: favours one extreme, shifts mean (e.g., antibiotic resistance) (1 mark)
Stabilising reduces variation around optimum (1 mark)
Directional increases frequency of advantageous extreme phenotype (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Define genetic drift and state when it is most significant. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Random changes in allele frequencies due to chance events (1 mark)
Most significant in small, isolated populations (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Describe bottleneck and founder effects as forms of drift. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Bottleneck: sharp reduction in population size reduces genetic diversity (1 mark)
Founder effect: new population started by few individuals has unrepresentative allele frequencies (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Give three types of molecular evidence used in modern classification. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: DNA sequence comparison/DNA barcoding (1 mark)
Comparative amino acid sequences of proteins (1 mark)
rRNA gene (e.g., 16S/18S) phylogenies/molecular clocks (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain the principle of a molecular clock and one limitation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Assumes mutations accumulate at ~constant rates to estimate divergence times (1 mark)
Rates vary among genes/lineages and selection can bias estimates (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: State two reasons why classification schemes change over time. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: New molecular/fossil evidence reveals different relationships (1 mark)
Revised species concepts and improved analytical methods (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: List three sources of evidence for evolution. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Fossil record and transitional forms (1 mark)
Comparative anatomy/embryology (1 mark)
Molecular homology/biogeography (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain how courtship behaviour can contribute to speciation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Species-specific signals cause behavioural isolation (1 mark)
Prevents interbreeding, promoting reproductive isolation (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Describe how antibiotic resistance in bacteria illustrates natural selection. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Random mutations confer resistance to an antibiotic (1 mark)
Antibiotic treatment kills susceptible bacteria, resistant survive (1 mark)
Resistant strains reproduce and spread the resistance alleles (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Give two differences between artificial selection and natural selection. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Artificial selection driven by human choice of traits; natural selection by environmental pressures (1 mark)
Artificial selection can reduce genetic diversity; natural selection maintains/adapts to environments (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Name two common data types used to build a dichotomous key and one limitation of keys. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Morphological characters (e.g., leaf shape, segment number) (1 mark)
Observable behaviours/habitats or simple molecular traits (1 mark)
Keys may fail with intraspecific variation or missing characters (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain why 16S rRNA gene sequences are widely used for prokaryote classification. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Conserved function across bacteria with variable regions informative for phylogeny (1 mark)
Present in all prokaryotes and allows alignment across diverse taxa (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Define monophyletic, paraphyletic and polyphyletic groups. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Monophyletic: ancestor and all descendants (clade) (1 mark)
Paraphyletic: ancestor and some, not all, descendants (1 mark)
Polyphyletic: groups with different recent ancestors lumped by similarity (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Outline steps to construct a simple phylogenetic tree from DNA sequences. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Select homologous gene/region and obtain sequences (1 mark)
Align sequences to identify homologous positions (1 mark)
Calculate genetic distances or choose a substitution model (1 mark)
Infer tree using parsimony/maximum likelihood/neighbor-joining (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Describe ring species and what they demonstrate about speciation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Populations distributed in a ring with neighbouring interbreeding but terminal forms reproductively isolated (1 mark)
Illustrates continuous variation leading to speciation despite gene flow (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain how hybrid sterility supports the biological species concept. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Hybrids (e.g., mule) are sterile due to chromosomal incompatibilities (1 mark)
Prevents gene flow, maintaining species boundaries (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Give two reasons fossil evidence can be incomplete or biased. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Soft tissues rarely fossilise; preservation favours certain environments (1 mark)
Sampling and discovery biases distort the record (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Describe three assumptions/requirements of using morphological characters in classification. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Characters are heritable and homologous (1 mark)
Character states can be compared across taxa reliably (1 mark)
Convergence and plasticity are accounted for to avoid misclassification (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Discuss how climate change can drive evolutionary change in populations. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Alters selection pressures (e.g., temperature/precipitation) (1 mark)
Favors alleles conferring tolerance or altered phenology (1 mark)
Shifts ranges causing new interactions/gene flow (1 mark)
Populations may adapt, migrate or face local extinction (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Design an investigation to compare species richness along an altitudinal gradient and relate it to a phylogenetic pattern. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Select transects across altitude bands with replicated plots (1 mark)
Record species presence/abundance using standardised quadrats/traps (1 mark)
Calculate richness/evenness per band and environmental variables (1 mark)
Collect barcoding sequences (e.g., rbcL/COI) for representative taxa (1 mark)
Build phylogeny and test for phylogenetic clustering/overdispersion (1 mark)
Analyse relationships between environment, diversity and phylogenetic structure (1 mark)

2.2 Classification and evolution.question: Explain why monophyletic taxa are preferred in modern classification. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: They accurately reflect evolutionary history/common ancestry (1 mark)
Improve predictive power for traits and comparative biology (1 mark)

1.1 Cellular control.question: Define a gene mutation. [1 mark]
