1.3 Manipulating genomes.question: Summarise the Southern blot technique. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Digest genomic DNA and separate by gel electrophoresis (1 mark)
Transfer DNA to a membrane (blotting) (1 mark)
Hybridise with a labelled probe to detect target fragments (1 mark)

1.3 Manipulating genomes.question: Give three ELSI (ethical, legal, social) issues associated with personal genomic data. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Privacy and data security of genetic information (1 mark)
Informed consent for testing and data use (1 mark)
Risk of genetic discrimination or misuse by third parties (1 mark)

1.3 Manipulating genomes.question: State three factors when choosing restriction enzymes for cloning a gene. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Sites absent within the insert/open reading frame (1 mark)
Compatible cohesive ends with the vector MCS (1 mark)
Optimal buffer/temperature and minimal star activity (1 mark)

1.3 Manipulating genomes.question: Why is Taq polymerase used in standard PCR? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: It is thermostable and remains active at high denaturation temperatures (1 mark)

1.3 Manipulating genomes.question: What is real-time PCR (qPCR) used for? Name one detection chemistry. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Quantification of DNA (or cDNA in RT-qPCR) during amplification (1 mark)
Uses fluorescent dyes (e.g., SYBR Green) or hydrolysis probes (TaqMan) (1 mark)

1.3 Manipulating genomes.question: List four basic rules for designing a PCR primer pair. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Length ~18–25 bases with 40–60% GC content (1 mark)
Similar melting temperatures (Tm ~55–65 °C) for both primers (1 mark)
Avoid hairpins, repeats and primer–dimer complementarity (1 mark)
Place a 3′ GC clamp and target unique regions (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Define biotechnology. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The industrial or commercial use of living organisms or their products to make useful substances or processes (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Define cloning. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Production of genetically identical cells or organisms from a single parent (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Distinguish natural from artificial cloning in plants. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Natural cloning occurs via vegetative propagation (e.g., runners, tubers) without human intervention (1 mark)
Artificial cloning involves human techniques such as cuttings or tissue culture to produce clones (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Give two natural methods of vegetative propagation with a named example. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Runners/stolons (e.g., strawberry) (1 mark)
Tubers/bulbs/rhizomes (e.g., potato/onion) (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Outline the steps for producing a successful stem cutting. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Select healthy, disease-free parent and cut below a node (1 mark)
Remove lower leaves and optionally wound base (1 mark)
Dip in rooting hormone/auxin and place in moist, aerated medium (1 mark)
Maintain high humidity and warmth to encourage root formation (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Define micropropagation and state one advantage. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Micropropagation: in-vitro cloning using small explants/tissue culture (1 mark)
Advantage: rapid production of many disease-free, uniform plants year-round (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: List four key stages of plant tissue culture. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Surface sterilise and take explant (1 mark)
Place on sterile nutrient agar with plant hormones to form callus (1 mark)
Transfer to media with different auxin:cytokinin ratios for shoot/root formation (1 mark)
Acclimatise plantlets and transfer to soil (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Explain the roles of auxins and cytokinins in micropropagation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: High cytokinin:auxin promotes shoot formation (1 mark)
High auxin:cytokinin promotes root formation (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: State two advantages of cloning plants. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Guaranteed desirable genotype/phenotype retained (uniformity) (1 mark)
Rapid, large-scale production from limited or sterile material (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: State two disadvantages of cloning plants. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Reduced genetic variation increases vulnerability to disease (1 mark)
Potential for systemic spread of undetected mutations/somatic errors (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Compare reproductive and non-reproductive cloning in animals. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Reproductive cloning produces a live offspring/genetically identical animal (1 mark)
Non-reproductive cloning produces tissues/organs/cell lines for therapy or research (1 mark)
Both use embryo splitting or nuclear transfer but have different endpoints (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Outline embryo splitting and somatic cell nuclear transfer (SCNT). [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Embryo splitting: early embryo is divided to form several identical embryos (1 mark)
Each embryo implanted into a surrogate for development (1 mark)
SCNT: somatic nucleus inserted into enucleated egg and activated (1 mark)
Embryo develops clonally and is implanted into a surrogate (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Give three ethical or practical concerns with animal cloning. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Low success rates/high embryo loss and welfare issues (1 mark)
Premature ageing/abnormal gene expression/epigenetic errors (1 mark)
Concerns over biodiversity, identity and use of animals (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Explain why microorganisms are widely used in biotechnology. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Rapid growth and reproduction with simple nutrient needs (1 mark)
Can be grown on waste substrates under controlled conditions (1 mark)
Produce a wide range of products and are ethically acceptable (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Name and describe the four phases of a typical microbial growth curve in batch culture. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Lag: adaptation, enzyme synthesis, little division (1 mark)
Log/exponential: maximum rate of division (1 mark)
Stationary: nutrient depletion/waste accumulation, growth = death (1 mark)
Death/decline: cells die faster than they divide (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Give three factors that can limit microbial growth in culture. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Nutrient depletion or substrate limitation (1 mark)
Oxygen availability or build-up of toxic wastes (1 mark)
Temperature or pH moving away from optimum (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Contrast batch and continuous fermentation. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Batch: closed culture, fixed volume, product harvested at end (1 mark)
Continuous: fresh medium added and culture removed to maintain growth (1 mark)
Batch suited to secondary metabolites (e.g., antibiotics) (1 mark)
Continuous suited to primary metabolites/biomass (e.g., SCP) (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: List four key features of an industrial fermenter and their functions. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Temperature control (jacket/cooling coils) to maintain optimum (1 mark)
pH probes with automatic acid/alkali dosing (1 mark)
Aeration and agitation/impellers for oxygen distribution (1 mark)
Aseptic design/filters to prevent contamination (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Why is aseptic technique essential in biotechnology and give two steps used. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Prevents contamination that reduces yield or introduces hazards (1 mark)
Flame sterilise equipment/work near a flame or in a cabinet (1 mark)
Disinfect surfaces and use sterile media/closed vessels (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Outline how to streak-plate bacteria to obtain single colonies. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Sterilise loop and cool before use (1 mark)
Streak sample across quadrants, flaming between sectors (1 mark)
Incubate inverted plates at suitable temperature (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Describe a serial dilution and viable count procedure. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Make stepwise tenfold dilutions of the culture (1 mark)
Plate known volumes on agar and incubate (1 mark)
Count colonies and back-calculate CFU per cm³ (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Distinguish primary from secondary metabolites with an example. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Primary metabolites are produced during active growth (e.g., ethanol/enzymes) (1 mark)
Secondary metabolites produced later (e.g., antibiotics like penicillin) (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: State which culture mode is preferred for penicillin and why. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Batch culture (1 mark)
Penicillin is a secondary metabolite best produced in stationary phase (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Define bioremediation and give one example. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Use of microorganisms to remove pollutants from the environment (1 mark)
E.g., bacteria degrading oil spills or solvents in contaminated soil (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Define immobilised enzymes and list three immobilisation methods. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Enzymes fixed to or within an inert matrix so they do not freely diffuse (1 mark)
Entrapment in alginate/gel or encapsulation in beads (1 mark)
Adsorption or covalent bonding to a solid support/cross-linking (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Give four advantages of using immobilised enzymes in industry. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Enzymes can be reused and recovered easily (1 mark)
Product not contaminated with enzyme (1 mark)
Greater stability over wider pH/temperature ranges (1 mark)
Continuous processing in columns is feasible (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: State three possible disadvantages of immobilised enzymes. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lower reaction rate due to diffusion limitations (1 mark)
Cost of immobilisation/support materials (1 mark)
Enzyme may detach/denature during operation (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Give three industrial uses of immobilised enzymes with the enzyme named. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lactase to produce lactose-free milk (1 mark)
Glucose isomerase to convert glucose to fructose (HFCS) (1 mark)
Penicillin acylase to make semi-synthetic antibiotics (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Outline key conditions for large-scale penicillin production by Penicillium chrysogenum. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Batch culture with carefully controlled aeration and pH (1 mark)
Low sugar after initial growth to trigger secondary metabolism (1 mark)
Addition of precursor side-chain molecules as required (1 mark)
Temperature control and asepsis throughout (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Describe how mycoprotein (single-cell protein) is produced from Fusarium. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Continuous, aerobic culture on carbohydrate/ammonia minerals (1 mark)
Aeration and agitation to maintain high growth rates (1 mark)
Biomass harvested, heat-treated to reduce RNA (1 mark)
Texturised/flavoured and processed as food (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Define downstream processing and name two typical steps. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Purification and processing of product after fermentation (1 mark)
Cell removal/filtration or centrifugation (1 mark)
Chromatography/crystallisation/concentration steps (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Why is foam problematic in fermenters and how is it controlled? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Foam reduces gas transfer and can cause contamination/overflow (1 mark)
Mechanical breakers or sterile antifoam agents are used (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Give two reasons recombinant human insulin from bacteria is widely used. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Identical to human insulin → fewer immune reactions (1 mark)
Ethical/religious acceptability and reliable supply (1 mark)
High purity and scalable production (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: What is a chemostat and why is it used in continuous culture? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: A fermenter where fresh medium is added and culture removed at a set rate (1 mark)
Maintains cells at a chosen growth rate by limiting a specific nutrient (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Give three sustainability advantages of single-cell protein (SCP). [3 marks]
mark_scheme: High protein yield per area/time compared with livestock (1 mark)
Can use waste substrates and less water/land (1 mark)
Independent of climate/season, produced near demand (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: State two biosafety measures when working with genetically modified microbes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Use of biological containment/auxotrophic strains (1 mark)
Physical containment and waste sterilisation before disposal (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Why can total cell counts exceed viable counts in a culture sample? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Total counts include dead or non-culturable cells (1 mark)
Viable counts only include colony-forming units after incubation (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Explain why oxygen supply must be carefully controlled in aerobic and anaerobic processes. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Aerobic: sufficient O₂ needed for respiration and high yield (1 mark)
Excessive aeration can cause shear stress/foaming (1 mark)
Anaerobic: O₂ must be excluded to favour desired pathways/products (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: When would micropropagation be preferred over seed propagation? Give two reasons. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: When the parent is heterozygous and uniformity is required (1 mark)
When seeds are scarce/sterile or slow to germinate (1 mark)
For rapid disease-free multiplication of elite stock (1 mark)

2.1 Cloning and biotechnology.question: Design a simple investigation to compare free vs immobilised lactase activity. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Prepare equal enzyme activities: free lactase and alginate-bead immobilised lactase (1 mark)
Control variables: substrate (lactose) concentration, temperature, pH, volume (1 mark)
Run reactions in parallel and sample at timed intervals (1 mark)
Measure glucose produced using a colorimetric test/strip or biosensor (1 mark)
Plot rate (glucose per minute) for each condition (1 mark)
Conclude on rate, reusability and stability differences (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Define an ecosystem. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A community of organisms interacting with each other and with the abiotic environment (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Distinguish between biotic and abiotic factors, giving one example of each. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Biotic factors are living components that affect organisms (e.g., competition/predation) (1 mark)
Abiotic factors are non-living components (e.g., temperature/light intensity) (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: State what is meant by a trophic level. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The position an organism occupies in a food chain/web based on its feeding level (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Name the organisms at the first trophic level and the general name for those at the second trophic level. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: First trophic level: producers (autotrophs) (1 mark)
Second trophic level: primary consumers (herbivores) (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Define gross primary productivity (GPP) and net primary productivity (NPP). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: GPP: total chemical energy fixed by producers per unit area per unit time (1 mark)
NPP: energy in plant biomass available to next trophic level after respiratory losses (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: A crop has GPP = 2100 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ and plant respiration R = 1200 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹. Calculate NPP. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: NPP = GPP − R (1 mark)
NPP = 900 kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Explain why energy transfer between trophic levels is inefficient. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Not all biomass is eaten (egestion/uneaten parts) (1 mark)
Energy lost as heat via respiration/movement (1 mark)
Excretion and indigestible material reduce transfer (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Define a decomposer and a detritivore. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Decomposer: microorganism that secretes enzymes to break down organic matter externally (saprotrophic nutrition) (1 mark)
Detritivore: organism that ingests dead organic material to increase surface area for decomposers (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Outline the role of decomposers in nutrient recycling. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Break down complex organic compounds into inorganic ions (mineralisation) (1 mark)
Release nutrients (e.g., nitrate, phosphate) back to soil/water for uptake by producers (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Name the four main processes in the nitrogen cycle you are expected to describe. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Nitrogen fixation and ammonification (1 mark)
Nitrification and denitrification (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Describe the roles of Rhizobium and Nitrosomonas in the nitrogen cycle. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Rhizobium: symbiotic nitrogen fixation (N₂ → NH₄⁺) in legume root nodules (1 mark)
Nitrosomonas: oxidises NH₄⁺ to NO₂⁻ (nitrification) (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: State the environmental conditions that favour denitrification and name a denitrifying product. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Anaerobic/waterlogged, low-oxygen soils favour denitrification (1 mark)
Produces N₂ or N₂O gas (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: List four key processes in the carbon cycle. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Photosynthesis fixes atmospheric CO₂ (1 mark)
Respiration releases CO₂ (1 mark)
Decomposition returns CO₂ to atmosphere/soil (1 mark)
Combustion of biomass/fossil fuels releases CO₂ (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Explain how deforestation can alter the carbon cycle. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Reduces photosynthetic uptake of CO₂ (1 mark)
Increases CO₂ via burning and decomposition of cleared biomass (1 mark)
Reduces long-term carbon sequestration in forest biomass/soil (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Define ecological succession. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A directional change in a community’s species composition over time (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Distinguish primary and secondary succession. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Primary starts on newly formed, lifeless substrate with no soil (e.g., lava, sand) (1 mark)
Secondary follows disturbance where soil/seeds remain (e.g., after fire) (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Describe three adaptations of pioneer species that enable colonisation of bare substrate. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Tolerance to desiccation/extremes (1 mark)
Ability to fix nitrogen or trap dust to build soil (1 mark)
Rapid reproduction/seed dispersal and small seeds (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Outline the sequence of changes from bare rock to a climatic climax community. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Pioneer species (lichens/mosses) weather rock and form thin soil (1 mark)
Herbs and grasses establish as soil depth/organic matter increase (1 mark)
Shrubs and early successional trees outcompete pioneers (1 mark)
Stable climax community forms suited to climate (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Explain the term plagioclimax and give one management action that can create it. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: A deflected climax maintained by human activity (1 mark)
E.g., grazing/mowing/burning preventing woodland establishment (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Compare pyramids of numbers and pyramids of biomass. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Numbers show count of individuals at each trophic level; can be inverted (1 mark)
Biomass shows mass of living tissue; usually upright and better indicates energy (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: A herbivore ingests 1000 kJ and egests 400 kJ; 500 kJ is lost in respiration. Calculate production efficiency as a percentage. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Assimilated energy = 1000 − 400 = 600 kJ (1 mark)
Secondary production = 600 − 500 = 100 kJ (1 mark)
Production efficiency = (100/600) × 100 = 16.7% (approx.) (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: State two reasons why biomass is measured as dry mass rather than fresh mass. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Water content varies widely between samples (1 mark)
Dry mass reflects actual organic material/energy content (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Give the usual units for (i) biomass and (ii) productivity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Biomass: g m⁻² (or kg m⁻²) (1 mark)
Productivity: g m⁻² yr⁻¹ or kJ m⁻² yr⁻¹ (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Explain how mycorrhizae can enhance plant growth in ecosystems. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Fungal hyphae increase root surface area for water/mineral uptake (1 mark)
Mutualistic exchange: plant provides carbohydrates to fungus (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: List three abiotic factors you could measure in a field study and a suitable instrument for one. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Light intensity, soil pH, soil moisture, temperature, wind speed (any three) (1 mark)
Light intensity measured with a light meter (1 mark)
Soil pH with a pH probe or indicator kit (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Describe how to obtain a random sample of ground plant cover using quadrats. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lay out two tape measures to form coordinates over the area (1 mark)
Use random number generator to select coordinates (1 mark)
Place quadrat at each coordinate and record percentage cover/frequency (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Differentiate between a line transect and a belt transect. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Line transect: record species that touch a line at intervals (1 mark)
Belt transect: place quadrats along a strip for abundance data (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Explain why systematic sampling along an environmental gradient is useful in succession studies. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Captures directional change in communities across the gradient (1 mark)
Allows correlation of species abundance with changing abiotic factors (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Give three factors that affect the rate of decomposition. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Temperature (higher speeds enzyme activity to a point) (1 mark)
Moisture/oxygen availability (aerobic decomposers need O₂) (1 mark)
Substrate quality/surface area (lignin content/particle size) (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Outline how eutrophication can result from agricultural runoff. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Fertiliser leaches nitrates/phosphates into water (1 mark)
Algal bloom forms, increasing turbidity (1 mark)
Decomposition of dead algae increases BOD, using O₂ (1 mark)
Hypoxia kills aquatic animals and reduces biodiversity (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Explain the term net ecosystem productivity (NEP) and its relationship to GPP and ecosystem respiration (Rₑ). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: NEP is net carbon accumulation in the ecosystem (1 mark)
NEP = GPP − Rₑ (plant + heterotroph respiration) (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: State two ways land managers can increase primary productivity in agricultural ecosystems. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Optimise light/water/nutrient availability (e.g., irrigation/fertiliser) (1 mark)
Reduce pest/herbivore damage (e.g., pesticides/biological control) (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Explain why food chains rarely exceed four or five trophic levels. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Cumulative energy loss limits energy available at higher levels (1 mark)
Insufficient biomass/energy to support additional levels (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Describe two ways animal husbandry can increase secondary productivity. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Selective breeding/high-energy feed to increase growth (1 mark)
Temperature control/reduced movement to reduce respiratory losses (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Give two reasons why seasonal changes can alter species distributions within an ecosystem. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Abiotic factors (temperature/photoperiod) change resource availability (1 mark)
Life cycles/migration cause temporal shifts in populations (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Define niche and explain why two species with identical niches cannot coexist indefinitely. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Niche: the role and requirements of a species in its environment (1 mark)
Competitive exclusion: one outcompetes the other for limiting resources (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Explain how detritivores accelerate decomposition and nutrient cycling. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Physically fragment litter, increasing surface area (1 mark)
Enhance microbial access and enzymatic breakdown (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Suggest one case-study example of a managed plagioclimax and the action used to maintain it. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Heathland/moorland maintained by periodic burning or grazing (1 mark)
Management prevents succession to woodland, preserving heath species (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Describe two potential impacts of climate change on ecosystem function. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Shifts in species ranges/phenology altering interactions (1 mark)
Changes in NPP and decomposition rates affecting carbon balance (1 mark)

3.1 Ecosystems.question: Discuss six differences between early (pioneer) and late (climax) communities during succession. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Early: low biomass; Late: high biomass (1 mark)
Early: few species/low diversity; Late: many species/higher diversity (1 mark)
Early: simple food webs; Late: complex food webs (1 mark)
Early: small, fast-growing r-selected species; Late: larger K-selected species (1 mark)
Early: low stability/high fluctuation; Late: greater stability (1 mark)
Early: low humus/poor soils; Late: deeper soils with more humus/nutrients (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Define a population. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A group of organisms of the same species living in the same place at the same time (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Define carrying capacity. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The maximum population size an environment can sustain over time (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Distinguish density-dependent and density-independent limiting factors with an example of each. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Density-dependent factors intensify as population increases (e.g., disease/competition) (1 mark)
Density-independent factors affect populations regardless of density (e.g., frost/flood) (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Give two biotic factors that can limit population growth. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Intraspecific or interspecific competition (1 mark)
Predation or disease/parasitism (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Describe the general shape and phases of a logistic (sigmoid) population growth curve. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lag phase with slow growth as individuals acclimatise (1 mark)
Log/exponential phase with rapid growth under plentiful resources (1 mark)
Stationary phase as carrying capacity is reached and births ≈ deaths (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Explain why the lag and stationary phases occur in population growth. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Lag: low numbers/juveniles/enzymatic induction lead to slow reproduction (1 mark)
Stationary: resource limitation and waste accumulation increase mortality (1 mark)
Stationary: density-dependent factors reduce birth rate/increase death rate (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Differentiate intraspecific from interspecific competition and state one likely outcome of each. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Intraspecific: within a species; regulates population size via territoriality/resource sharing (1 mark)
Interspecific: between species; can lead to competitive exclusion or niche partitioning (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Explain typical predator–prey population cycles. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Prey increase leads to predator increase with a time lag (1 mark)
Predation reduces prey, causing predator decline (1 mark)
Lower predation allows prey recovery and the cycle repeats (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Outline the mark–release–recapture (MRR) method to estimate population size. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Capture a sample, mark individuals harmlessly and record number marked (M) (1 mark)
Release marked individuals and allow time to mix with the population (1 mark)
Recapture a second sample and count total caught (C) and number marked in it (R) (1 mark)
Estimate N using Lincoln index N ≈ (M × C) / R (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Write the Lincoln index formula used in MRR and define each term. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: N ≈ (M × C) / R (1 mark)
M = first sample marked, C = second sample size, R = marked recaptures (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: State three assumptions of mark–release–recapture. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Population is closed: no significant immigration/emigration/births/deaths (1 mark)
Marks are not lost and do not affect survival/behaviour (1 mark)
Marked individuals mix fully and have equal catchability as unmarked (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Give two ways to reduce bias when using quadrats to sample plant populations. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Use random or stratified-random positioning with random coordinates (1 mark)
Use sufficient replicates/consistent estimation of percentage cover (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: In an MRR study, 80 beetles are marked (M = 80). A week later 100 beetles are caught (C = 100), 20 of which are marked (R = 20). Estimate population size. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Use N ≈ (M × C) / R (1 mark)
N ≈ 400 beetles (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Define sustainable yield. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: The harvest level that can be maintained indefinitely without reducing the population or resource base (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: Distinguish maximum sustainable yield (MSY) from optimum sustainable yield (OSY). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: MSY ≈ largest long-term average catch theoretically sustainable at carrying capacity (1 mark)
OSY is a more conservative harvest below MSY accounting for uncertainty and ecosystem needs (1 mark)

3.2 Populations and sustainability.question: State two features of selective felling compared with clear felling in forestry. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Selective felling removes only chosen trees, retaining canopy structure (1 mark)
Reduces soil erosion/biodiversity loss compared with clear felling (1 mark)
